headline: President Trump's CIA pick faces questions over her role in enhanced interrogation program

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Hi, I'm Greg Gutfeld with Kimberly Guilfoyle, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters, and a pistachio shell is her canoe, Dana Perino -- "The Five." Here's an experiment: type "torture" into Google and what do you get? Beyond snippets of Hillary's speeches, you'll see Gina Haspel, the first woman to be nominated to run the CIA. A 33-year vet, more than qualified to run the place with deep knowledge of our worst enemies and how to handle them, which means she must be stopped:

utterances.speaker: JOHN BERMAN, CNN
utterances.sentences: On the other hand, there is controversy in her past. She was involved with the torture program after September 11th, and then, involved with destroying videotapes of the matter. Also, that might be something that could be problematic.

utterances.speaker: SEN. RAND PAUL, R-KY.
utterances.sentences: I oppose her because she believes in waterboarding should be something that we use, and I think America shouldn't be known for torture.

utterances.speaker: JEREMY SCAHILL, THE INTERCEPT
utterances.sentences: Gina Haspel does not belong as head of the CIA. She belongs in front of a judge answering to what she was doing running a torture operation at a black site in Thailand.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They dig pretty deep for that one. All right.  Fact is, Gina made decisions that few people ever have to make. The world she operated in and the villains she faced, she didn't have the luxury of just talking about what to do, she had to do, because the call she answered demanded it. So, was it torture? It wasn't back then. And just because you don't like a tactic, that doesn't make it torture. Of course, you could discuss the merits of such choices with pundits on TV rather than doing her job. She'd probably be paid more. But instead, she took the risk and responsibility, so we didn't have to. She responded not just to the worst attack on our country since Pearl Harbor, but to a world-ending threat.   Sure, it's easy to say, but we're better than that, from a shiny newsroom. But if you think whatever she did was wrong, what is your alternative? Do you have anything beyond "don't do that"? Have you ever even thought this through all the way? So here's a question for Haspel's critics" Imagine being in a situation where your family is in danger and a terrorist is withholding key information that could save them. Would you still consider "enhanced interrogation" sadism? With everything that's considered "mean" be off the table? Something tells me you'd rather leave that question up to people like Gina Haspel. So, Dana, you know this story probably better than anybody. They keep calling this torture. Do they have a reason to call this stuff torture? I don't -- it's an opinion.

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Well, it's their personal opinion. There has never been a legal opinion.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Three attorneys general have looked into this. All of them have declined to prosecute. The program was ended when it was no longer needed. And I think about her in terms of a three-decade career at the CIA. And all of a sudden, now she's not suitable to work at the CIA? She's been the deputy director of the CIA for the last year and a half. She has a great reputation amongst, not just Republicans, she's been serving since 41's administration, but also with the Obama team.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And what I would ask people to think about is, have we forgotten what it was like on the morning after 9/11?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And what was happening? She was actually following orders, OK? She did follow orders that were based on a lawful program asked for by the President of the United States. And to the subject of that she destroyed evidence, there was no case that was ongoing when those tapes were destroyed. And that might seem to some people like a distinction without a difference, but let me just tell you if you're in the CIA, do you have reason to believe that the congressional members of congress who are going to use this for decades. Now, we're almost 17 years after the fact and they still want to, you know, pick at this scab and not allow a woman who has an amazing record of public service to be able to serve? That really chaps my hide.  If there are clear reasons that she should not be allowed to run this department that have nothing to do with her work, that has not been questioned. The program does not exist anymore.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That to me, if there's a substantial reason, fine. Let's have that discussion. But this one -- and grandstanding is so despicable.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And it's going to happen. By the way, I think chapping your hide is worse than waterboarding, from what I understand.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, you could make that case.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, you could.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Anything that I don't like -- like, honestly, sleep deprivation, pulling out fingernails--

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Playing Greg's loud music the he played--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: They would definitely play that in a Thai prison.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: They do. What they do they play a lot of Metallica and Slayer, but to me that's not torture. That's beautiful music.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, one of the hardest briefings I ever had to do at the White House was, I woke up in the morning, got the New York Times, and there's the story that the CIA has destroyed interrogation tapes, and I thought oh, my gosh. And I had -- I talked to everybody that day, the president, the vice president, Mike Hayden, the former CIA director, and Steve Hadley, the national security advisor.  And I remember just having a private moment with Steve Hadley before I went to the briefing and he said, Dana, I just want to explain something to you. In those days after 9/11, this country had to make some really tough decisions, and they were tough, but they were legal and they saved lives. And I went out and I had the best briefing I'd ever had because I was confident.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think it's something hard to argue against her, but they will argue again. So Kimberly, if she was a Democrat and it was under Hillary, they would say any opposition to her would be sexist.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Should we say that? Because she's a woman, do you think it's sexist?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think it's ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: You want us to say it, we'll say it. It's sexist.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Is that going to help?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: But she's qualified. She deserves -- OK, Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: OK, don't worry.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A lot of things make you nuts.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yeah. But she's right, torture is anything, sitting right here.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: What else? I don't like beets very much--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: -- right? That's about it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But you love super beets.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah. Those advertisers, Kimberly, just lets pay the bills.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Exactly. Take it easy there. All right, let me slow my role. I think that she's unbelievably qualified. And whether male, female, based on her record, a career of distinction, someone who's able to make tough decisions, who is widely admired by her peers, she deserves this position. They're going to be in a tough spot. It works the other way because she's a female, because then they will say, OK--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: -- why are you making these attacks against her? This could be considered sexist. She should get the job, and I do think they're going to pull a whole, you know, pork on her because--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: -- some of the background and tactics. And you know what, because they're going to like the fanfare--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly, high drama.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: -- fodder for certain shows.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Plus, the more they talk about this, the more President Trump is going to like her.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah, exactly. And it will be -- Jesse, there'll be Democrats galloping in on their moral high horses. There's also be Rand Paul, who's now going to oppose Pompeo and Haspel. He's great.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah. The moral high horse, and the Democrats, the Obama intelligence agencies that spied on reporters, that lied to the American people in front of congress, that did a lot of really disgusting things and they didn't bat an eyelash then. So get off your high horse, get off your soapbox. This woman is a patriot. She was trying to save lives after 9/11. I remember, George Bush on his last press conference said exactly what you said. You don't remember what it was like here after 9/11. They had to make a lot of tough decisions. And she made some tough decisions. And the head of her operation, Jose Rodriguez, says enhanced interrogation saved lives and foiled plots. You know who also said it? Leon Panetta, the Obama intelligence chief. And he said that enhanced interrogation led to the location of Osama Bin Laden. Speaking of Leon, also Brennan, Clapper, and Morell, all the top intelligence people under the Obama administration all support this woman. So does Dianne Feinstein, which I find interesting -- Stein, excuse me. And the whole thing about her destroying the tapes, so she was told to destroy tapes and she did. Hillary destroyed tapes because she wanted to and that was under an active investigation.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You have to admire what he just did there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And the justice department let them both off the hook, so that's fine. Now--

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Fair and fair.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This is a perfect example of media bias, because this is a woman who's about to shatter the glass ceiling.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So she should be praised by the left-wing media. But instead, she's trying to be railroaded because she was nominated by a Republican. And the media for years has been saying that women should be celebrated because they're playing in the big boy's league, and they're tough, and we need tough women that can really, you know, take the fight to people. Now, we actually have a woman like that who made terrorists whine and whimper and they're trying to attack her.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know what scares me, I think that Democrat husbands are going to tell their wives not to supporter her--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- and they won't because they're so subservient. All right, Juan, I'm going to give you the argument that I always hear that our tactics, interrogation tactics, fueled the people who hate us. It's like we just make it worse because we're lowering ourselves to that level. Is that how you feel?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.sentences: Yeah. I don't think it's very American to torture people, and neither does John McCain, who was tortured.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Not torture.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So what you get is -- and it is torture. It's what we're talking about.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Waterboarding is not torture.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Water -- well, I don't know. May be in your path -- you know, your free time you want to go--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't think that is rational or sane. Nobody in their right mind. So, I mean, maybe--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Then, what is your alternative? What's your plan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: There're lots of alternatives. In fact, if you go and talk to the intelligence community, they will tell you they get more out of people when they don't torture them. But here's the thing--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It depends.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- I think the key here is, will she renounce the use of torture in confirmation hearings? I think that's what Dianne Feinstein had to say today, which is, look, she's got a great reputation in the intelligence community. They call her a pro's pro. But the law has changed. Torture is illegal. But in this administration with President Trump, who by the way, is always putting down the CIA, but said he thinks torture is effective.  What about Mike Pompeo who was the former CIA director? He too has said, yeah, I think torture might work. So the question becomes, wait a second, are we going backwards here? Having had a moment of conscience about this, where we were torturing people even after the fact. It wasn't any -- like, you know, 24 scenario where, oh, we've got to get some information.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So we're just doing it for fun.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That has been now taken care of.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We have no conscience.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: The president can say -- the president has the right to say I need this information. Take extraordinary or enhanced interrogation tactics. But these people that she was torturing, those people--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Juan, you water bored me without the water.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: But it's like floppy to the word torture.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: How it's floppy?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I'll tell you right now--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It's like waterboarding because it's putting you in a box?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: So, yeah, some of these guys are real losers and real wimps, OK? They're crybabies. You put a caterpillar on their shoulder and they cry for their mom, and no more jihad and they spill it. So, that to me is not torture, it really isn't.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm just telling you.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: In the eye of the beholder, Juan, that's the problem.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Loud music or there's some sleep deprivation. There've been changes in the law, she will follow the law as it currently stand on the book.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's what I think. The key point is, will she renounce the use of torture?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana, would you break the law if you could save lives and ruin your career? Or would you follow the law and watch people die? That's an interesting question.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Break it, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: She didn't. I mean, that's a bad hypothetical.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, is it?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That leaves me to her saying that she didn't break any laws--

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Disqualified herself because--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I mean, obviously, this is not -- it's not an easy topic. The things that these agents are asked to do--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- are not easy. Do you think they want to do this? They've signed up to serve their country in order to protect us. But the notion that somehow Gitmo or these black sites somehow fueled more anger against western civilization is preposterous.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And that is a great point because after these enhanced interrogations were no longer used, the rise of ISIS--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- sprung up right after.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It's an ideology.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So what do they have to do with each other? While the other thing is--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What does that have to do with anything?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You said when we were interrogating people in a rough way that that was making them hate us even more.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You just set it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What I'm saying is that they hate us no matter what. It's an ideology that we're fighting. Anyway, I think that she'll end up with 75 votes in favor.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Good, all right. Excellent. Well, her arrest sparked an outcry spark from the left. We'll tell you the full story behind that video of an illegal immigrant pulled away from her daughters, ahead.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: A big immigration win for Texas. A federal appeals court has upheld its crackdown on sanctuary cities. More on that in a moment. Meanwhile, remember this video?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, an illegal immigrant mother arrested by U.S. border patrol, taken from her three screaming children earlier this month. Well, it's gotten a lot of attention. Protests erupted over it. But a key detail has been left out of the conversation. The woman was apprehended because she's suspected by the feds of organizing a human trafficking operation, which is one of the worst crimes against humanity, I think, Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yeah, no doubt. I mean, let me tell you something, some of the cases that we've investigated and took a look at are worst horrors of mankind that you can imagine with human trafficking and what happens here. And it's unbelievable that it doesn't get a bigger spotlight. The United Nations has been decent, you know, in terms of trying to profile and put this out here so that we can stop this, but it's like really widespread in countries you'd be very surprised of as well. So, when we do stories like this, I think it's really important that people knows that this is happening, that this is going on. To put, you know, better awareness of it, and also to report abuses.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, it's hard, Juan, these cases are never necessarily black and white. It's complicated. Often, in order to protect the integrity of the case or the people that are involved, information is held back until the case is completed. In this case, the children were probably taken away, perhaps, to protect them. And so, there are other cases. We know of the woman from Congo who was separated from her daughter, and there's questions there. Why would the federal government do that? What do you think about this case?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I mean, obviously, human trafficking is reprehensible, but the way they did that was offensive. I mean, I think that's the upset is - - come to represent something larger which is separating parents from families and children.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And so, it picked up on something that resonates with the broader public, and that, you know, the way the ICE agents operate looks like they're above the law. They looked like cowboys jumping out and grabbing somebody. And in this case, separating a mother from her children. But I think--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Smuggler from her children.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't know what she is. I mean, I think that Dana is right to point out this awful charge of human smuggling involved, but that doesn't excuse the behavior of ICE agents. I don't think that we want to see police or anybody acting in that fashion.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't think the police was that bad. I mean, I understand like ripping a mother away from her children, but in this case, I mean, the mother put the children in a bad position.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah. It's the mom's fault that she was then hauled off like that. She's got stuck in the patty. You know, don't do the crime if you can't do the time, Juan. Do you want to be treated equally under the justice system? Man or woman? Illegal, legal? Listen, I believe the ICE agents in this case. Sorry, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All of it was an allegation. This is America, still, you know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan, she's going to go through due process. That's fine. I didn't see her hurting this woman. I didn't see her throwing any elbows. I thought they were treating her fine. She was the one resisting.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Oh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: She was the one screaming and causing a scene. You know what, if the ICE show up for me, I'd go like this and get in the back of the wagon and have my lawyer deal with it. I found some interesting polling, Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: No, you take your phone out for sure.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know Juan loves polling. And I found something that's going to blow his entire argument out of the water here.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right, go for it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Sanctuary city poll, and it's done by Greg's alma mater, Berkeley, so we know it's correct, 74 percent of Californians opposed sanctuary cities. Sixty five percent of Hispanics in California oppose sanctuary cities. And 73 percent of Democrats in California oppose sanctuary cities.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, Greg, you could talk about either one just to build on that a little bit. Texas, yesterday, got some news from the federal appeals court, which has said that its ban on sanctuary cities can continue to take effect while legal challenges continue, so.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I would like to comment on that, but also on this arrest thing. Which one should I do first?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Whichever.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right. About the arrest, originally this was seen as a martyr and an innocent person, and that is because the media is always desperate to find their poster child for their specific issue. We've been guilty on the right, but mostly the left, the media, they always try to find that exact perfect victim and it never turns out. This is why -- if you see something that sounds too good to be true, they're ripping the mother away from the kids, it's probably not. Whenever we're about to do a story and we go, this sounds really, really, like, right up our alley, you've got to look at it and you'll find out there's a whole story behind that story. This is not -- you have to look at the background, and you find out it's too good to be true. Sorry, guys. You didn't get a poster child out of this one. To that story, the reason why the Republicans succeed on this sanctuary city thing is because liberals have yet to realize that a wish is not a plan. You know, wishing that everybody could come over here, it's not a plan. So the actual liberal plan for everything, from the welfare state to homelessness, illegal immigration, step one, wish. Step two, see step one. Republicans always have a step two. Step one is like, sure, we want to have good people coming over here. Step two, we want them to go through the proper entrance with an enforced border policy. That's step one too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm going to quote Scott Adams.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The problem is Democrats only offer--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Democrats only offer half a plan. They've got to have the wish, but they don't have the follow-through--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know what, you are engaged in a fantasy because I was reading--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But I just told you the truth.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, you told me a fantasy about wish and wishful thought--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- morning news today says, virtually no illegal border crossings in 2017, lowest since World War II--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: How did that happen?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No one crossed the border in 2017?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No, no, they've said lowest, virtually, the lowest since World War II. And here's Greg saying, oh, the Democrats just want people to march across -- this is ridiculous--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What do you think sanctuary cities are? What do they need to find at? If you come here, we will not stop you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: That's not the definition.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, am I missing something?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: To harbor criminals.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- you want people to cooperate with law enforcement--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, you bring that up, but there's no actual statistical evidence--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Tens of thousands of students across America walked out of their classrooms today to demand change to our nation's gun laws. The protest, next.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Today, students across the country participated in a nationwide school walkout to demand action on gun violence. Some prominent lawmakers joined their protest.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: A lot of us will also be 18 by November, and that's when midterm elections start.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: So I can promise you this, do your jobs, give us concrete solutions, and for once, value our lives over your bank accounts or we will vote you out.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: In the coming weeks and months, more of my peers will be slaughtered in their own classrooms, when their deaths will be dismissed as collateral, you know we have a moral problem in this country.

utterances.speaker: UNINDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I come to school to learn math and science, to be better in life, not to lose my life, and not have to learn how to dodge bullets.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: This afternoon, the house approved a bill to make schools safer and harden them against potential shootings. The stopped school violence act passed in a vote of 407-10, so very strong support, Greg, for this act.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: What's wrong?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A few things. Because we try to -- we tiptoe around this, because it's like teenagers. And I'm a little bit tired of tiptoeing. And -- but I want to be very careful about this. No. 1, I said a while ago you don't want to let these causes be hijacked by other causes. Women's march, Planned Parenthood, the Center for American Progress. That happened. That bugs me. No. 2, a protest should never be tied to a kind of implicit reward, meaning you're getting out of class. That taints it a little bit for me. I don't think the protest should accompany a reward. I think it should've been before class or after class. It has a feeling of a field trip. And you couple that with the attention you get from networks, it's a pretty exciting field trip. So I think there's a certain award -- reward there that taints the protest a bit. And then I'm also worried about what it's like for students who don't participate. Will their teachers and the students that they go to class with treat them differently? Will there be peer pressure? Will the teacher think less of them? You know, I did extra credit in high school for the nuclear freeze, a very left-wing thing. That amped up my grade. I got a better grade for doing that. So I think there is going to be a correlation between participating in this and how you're graded. But now the last thing, which is -- you know, it bothers me, is there's a bit of artificial restraint from parents or adults with this issue. It's like we're abdicating our responsibility to debate and criticize. We should be challenging teenagers, especially if they don't have the facts. If you're talking emotionally, you turn teenagers into adults by challenging them with facts. Emotion that's untethered to facts continues, especially when you're a teenager. I know. I was a teenager. I lived off emotion. I was a liberal. So I think that it's important. And also, you know, the FBI, an FBI executive just confirmed that there was an explicit, explicit tip about Cruz. So this isn't really about guns. It's about a lack of a follow-up, failure to catch a needle in a haystack, lack of a database that's very necessary. And I'm glad we're hardening the schools.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: I think this is more --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think that's important. No, I think we've heard -- we've heard from you on this every day.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE

Why wouldn't that be almost exigent circumstances that you should have in terms of public safety and how you've got a right to a peaceful and non-violent education in this country where you're not worried about what you're going to do if you're going to be shot or you have to hide in the school or what's going to happen. You're worried about, "OK, let me see if I can, like, learn how to do algebra today," or "Let me see if I can learn how to read more books, or do something or learn something in science or decide what I want to do with my future, because I'm going to have one, because they cared about my school safety."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.sentences: Yes, great.
